questions.text: The middle radioulnar joint belongs to which type of joint?
questions.solution:
Middle Radioulnar Joint is a type of Fibrous Joint which is joined by Syndesmosis as they are joined by interosseous membrane.

Types of joint:

  • Synovial
  • Cartilaginous
  • Fibrous - Syndesmoses and Gomphoses

Fibrous joints are connected by Dense connective tissue, mainly collagen.

Remember:

Superior and inferior radioulnar joints are pivot type of synovial joint. 

Superior tibio-fibular joint is a pivot variety of synovial joint whereas both middle and inferior tibio-fibular joint is an example of fibrous joint. 

Reference : Gray's Anatomy: The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice,41st Edition - page no.845,846,96-101

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct order of steps in  polymerase chain reaction (PCR)?
questions.solution:
The process of polymerase chain reaction involves Denaturation, Annealing, Extension

A. Denaturation - Separation of DNA by melting through 94 C for 3 minutes.
- Converts double stranded DNA to single stranded DNA

B. Annealing - Hybridization of two oligonucleotides used as primers to the target DNA to form template-primer hybridization complex. 
-At 3’end at 54C for 45seconds

C. Extension - Elongation of DNA chain by nucleotide addition from the primers
- Using DNA polymerase as catalyst in the presence of Mg2+ ions - At 72 C for 2 mins

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 452.

questions.text: What is the normality of 2M HCL in comparison to 1M H2SO4?
questions.solution:
Normality = Molarity x n where n is the number of H+ ions
In HCL, n is 1 whereas in H2SO4, n is 2
Normality of 2M HCL = 2 X 1 =2
Normality of 1M H2SO4 = 1 X 2 =2
Therefore, the normality of 2M HCL is SAME as that of 1M H2SO4.


Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 5

Which of the following enzymes is involved in the production of glucose?
A. Pyruvate carboxylase
B. Phosphoenolpyruvate kinase
C. Hexokinase
D. Pyruvate kinase
E. Glucose 6 phosphatase
questions.solution:
• The first step in gluconeogenesis is the conversion of pyruvate to phosphoenolpyruvic acid (PEP). In order to convert pyruvate to PEP there are several steps and several enzymes required.
  • Pyruvate carboxylase, PEP carboxykinase and malate dehydrogenase are the three enzymes responsible for this conversion in gluconeogenesis.

questions.text:
Which of the following causes ketosis in type 1 diabetes?
A. Decreased beta-oxidation of fatty acids
B. Increased mobilisation of fatty acid from adipose tissue
C. Decreased acetyl CoA entering to the TCA cycle
D. Increased beta- hydroxy butyrate dehydrogenase
questions.solution:
There is deficiency of insulin in type 1 DM. As a result, insulin mediated glucose uptake is not possible in adipose tissue and muscle for energy source.

Therefore, stored fat in adipose tissue is mobilized for generation of FFAs by beta oxidation which serve as precursors for ketone body synthesis. 

Also, since acetyl Co-A generated from breakdown of FFAs are directed towards ketone body synthesis, less is available to undergo oxidation via Kreb's cycle. 

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 146.

questions.text:
Alternate splicing occurs in a gene with segments 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 and a primer with the letters w, x, y, and z. It produces two goods, A and B.
Which primers are used to yield product A?
questions.solution:
Product A includes segment 1,3,4 and 5 in its structure.

Seg 1- Needs to be transcribed, so W is essential
Seg 2- Doesn't need to be transcribed
Seg 3- Needs to be transcribed, so Y is essential
Seg 4- Requires promotor Z but not essential since promotor Y can continue the transcription as indicated by the arrow.

There, the answer is promotor W and Y.

questions.text:
Which of the following assertions about the mechanisms of depolarization, repolarization, and hyperpolarization in the skeletal muscle action potential is correct?
A. Depolarisation due to influx of Na+ through voltage-gated channels
B. Depolarisation due to influx of Na+ through ligand- gated channels
C. Repolarisation due to efflux of K+through voltage - gated channels
D. Repolarisation due to efflux of K+ through ligand - gated channel
E. Hyperpolarization due to efflux of K+
questions.solution:
Skeletal muscle action potential:
  1. Resting membrane potential.
  2. Some voltage gated sodium channels open and sodium enters cell - Threshold potential.
  3. Opening of more voltage gated sodium channels, rapid upstroke - Depolarisation.
  4. Reached to peak level
  5. Sodium channels close with opening of voltage gated potassium channels - Repolarisation
  6. Slow return of potassium channels to closed state - Hyperpolarisation.
  7. Return to resting membrane potential.
 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 105

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is correct about skeletal muscle contraction
A. Extracellular Ca++ not important for contraction
B. Ca++ released from mitochondria
C. Ca++ releases from sarcoplasmic reticulum
D. Voltage gated Ca++ channel on sarcolemma has no role in EC coupling
E. Ca++ channel on sarcoplasmic reticulum has no role in EC coupling
questions.solution:
The true statements are- C. Storehouse of Ca++ ions in skeletal muscle is Sarcoplasmic reticulum A. Extracellular Ca++ is not important for contraction On receiving signal from the nerve terminal, changes in the sarcolemma’s resting potential cause release of calcium from its stores present in the sarcoplasmic reticulum. Hence, the skeletal muscle is not dependent on extracellular calcium for contraction.

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 105

questions.text:
What will be the sequence after the P wave

A. a wave
B. 1st heart sound
C. Filling of ventricles
D. T wave
questions.solution:
The correct sequence on cardiac cycle is  3. A -> C -> B - > D. 
Amongst given option correct answer would be a wave ->Ventricular filling ->1st heart sound ->T wave
 

  • A wave: After the P wave, the a wave on JVP occurs, which represents atrial contraction. This follows the depolarization of the atria (P wave), leading to the contraction of the atria and the push of blood into the ventricles.

  • Filling of ventricles: After the a wave, the ventricles fill with blood following the atrial contraction.(NOTE: 70% of ventricular filling is passive - only about 30% is due to atrial contraction)

  • 1st heart sound (S1): The first heart sound (S1) occurs when the AV valves (mitral and tricuspid) close, signaling the beginning of ventricular systole.

  • T wave: The T wave represents ventricular repolarization and occurs much later, after the ventricular contraction (systole) has finished.

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 529,530

questions.text: What happens when a person changes posture from supine to standing?
questions.solution:
When a person changes his posture from supine to standing, there is venous pooling in lower limbs.

This pooling causes decrease in the venous return which leads to decreased cardiac output.

This cascade continues and the decrease in cardiac output causes a similar decrease in blood pressure which leads to decreased firing from Baroreceptors.

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 666

questions.text: Which part is responsible for the formation of the macula densa?
questions.solution:
Macula densa is a part of Distal tubule.

They sense the Na+ concentration and take part in Tubulo-glomerular feedback.

questions.text: Which clotting factor deficiency will have no effect on clotting in vivo
questions.solution:
Among the clotting factor deficits listed, the clotting factor deficit that has no impact on clotting in vivo is factor XII (option 4). Factor XII, also known as Hageman factor, plays a role in the intrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade. However, its deficiency does not generally lead to bleeding or clotting abnormalities. This is because factor XII deficiency is not associated with significant clinical manifestations or bleeding disorders in most individuals.

Some coagulation factors and the diseases linked with their deficiency are:

   

According to new evidence, factor VIIa from the extrinsic pathway can activate factors XI and IX of intrinsic pathway, hence doing same work as that of XII, therefore factor XII deficiency doesn’t manifest much clinically.

 

Reference-: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease Edition 10 th Page no 120-122

questions.text: A 20-year-old female with easy fatiguability, pallor, hyperpigmented knuckles, and white nails. The findings from her hand are displayed below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:

questions.text: What is the most common retroperitoneal tumor?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is (Option 3) Liposarcoma

Most common retroperitoneal tumor is Liposarcoma. It is commonly seen in 5th to 7th decade of life with no specific gender predilection. 
 

They are classified histologically into five types-

  • ​well differentiated liposarcoma

    • also known as atypical lipomatous tumor

    • most common (~50%) 

    • has the highest amount of fat content

  • myxoid liposarcoma / round cell

    • second most common

    • intermediate grade (myxoid) or high grade (round cell)

    • balanced chromosomal translocation t(12,16)

  • dedifferentiated liposarcoma

    • high grade, aggressive with frequent metastases

  • pleomorphic liposarcoma

    • least common

    • high grade, aggressive with frequent metastases

  • myxoid pleomorphic

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1213.

questions.text: In HPE, which fixation technique is used for fat?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is (Option ) Frozen section

A frozen section is done for the fixation of fats. This ensures that the tissue need not to go through routine processing, which can remove lipids.

When tissue sample goes through rapid freezing, it becomes firmer. the ice acts as an embedding media allowing the tissue to be sectioned.

The goal of fixation is to create the matrix of cross-links to immobilize proteins that make up the tissue. As our body is made up of all kinds of proteins and lipids, carbohydrates, etc., creating a matrix of cross-links is incredibly important. Once we do that, we stop autolysis which is the self-destruction of the tissue.  Stopping autolysis prevents the tissue from acting upon itself as well as breaks down those intracellular proteins that will also prevent decomposition.



Reference: Wintrobe's Clinical hematology, 13 th edition, Page no. 43

Online Reference: Rachel C Hart, Darian T Carroll, Maria Vinogradova, Evan S Krystofiak, A Guide to Fixation and Staining of Biological Samples for Electron Microscopy, Microscopy Today, Volume 32, Issue 2, March 2024, Pages 37–40, https://doi.org/10.1093/mictod/qaae009

questions.text: A baby who was 14 months old and whose Hb level was 6.3 gm% received repeated blood transfusions during the previous nine months. Which of the following will be the best investigation for this patient's final diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Globin gene sequencing

Decreased hemoglobin levels, multiple target cells on peripheral smear and history of multiple blood transfusions point towards thalassemia.
In cases of thalassemia definitive diagnosis is done though Globin gene sequencing.

Investigations for hemoglobin disorders include:
  • Screening by hemoglobin electrophoresis.
  • Investigation of choice is HPLC.
  • Definitive diagnosis though globin gene sequencing.
* [Extra Edge]:

  • HbH disease, which is usually due to compound heterozygosity for one chromosome with both α-globin genes deleted and one chromosome with only a single α-globin gene, is defined by the hematologic findings along with varying levels of reticulocytosis.
  • At birth, when hemoglobin is separated by HPLC, 20–30% Hb Bart’s is present; in adults, traces to 40% HbH are present along with residual Hb Bart’s in some cases.
  • HbH inclusions can be induced in some red cells after incubation and staining with brilliant cresyl blue.
  • Hemoglobin composition in Hb Bart’s hydrops fetalis is predominantly Hb Bart’s with some Hb Portland if the deletion removing α-globin genes preserves the ζ-globin gene.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 645.

questions.text:
Match the following with the correct options.
Column A Column B
A. Silicosis 1. Crazy paving pattern
B. Mesothelioma 2. Malignant Plural effusion without mediastinal shift 
C. Caplan Syndrome 3. Initially demonstrated in coal workers
D. Asbestosis 4. Basal lobes involved
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 3) A-1, B-2, C-3, D-4
 
  • In silicosis, crazy paving pattern is seen on HRCT chest which represents ground glass opacity with septal thickening.
  • Malignant plural effusion can be with or without mediastinal shift. In cases of Mesothelioma, shift is absent.
  • Caplan syndrome was first demonstrated in coal workers.
  • Asbestosis, which is a type of pneumoconiosis is due to the deposition of asbestos bodies, usually involving the basal lobes of the lung. It's an exception since majority of pneumoconiosis have predilection for upper lobes of the lung.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 692.

questions.text: Which of the following is not considered to have reticular fibers as its structural support system?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Thymus
 
  • Reticular fibers are a type of collagen fiber that form a network of supporting tissue in many organs and tissues.
  • They are found in the spleen, lymph nodes, and bone marrow, where they provide structural support for the cells and tissues of these organs. However, they are not found in the thymus.
  • The thymus is a small, bilobed organ that is located in the upper chest.
  • It is responsible for the production of T cells, which are a type of white blood cell that plays a role in the immune system.
  •  The structural support of the thymus is provided by a network of epithelial cells and fibroblasts.
   



Reference: https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/medicine-and-dentistry/reticular-fiber

questions.text: What is the most likely primary site of a female with metastatic liver adenocarcinoma with CK7-, CK20+, and CDX-1 IHC markers
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Colorectal ca
 
  • CDX-1 + IHC marker for metastatic liver adenocarcinoma means colorectal carcinoma is the possible answer.
  • Transcription factors unique to the gut require genes CDX-1 and 2 which control intestine phenotypic development, differentiation, and maintenance.
  • CK7 and CK 20 are used to identify organ of origin in carcinoma of unknown primary. 
  • Colorectal Adeno Ca is ck 7 negative.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 814.

questions.text: Which clotting factor deficit has no impact on clotting in vivo?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: XII

Among the clotting factor deficits listed, the clotting factor deficit that has no impact on clotting in vivo is factor XII (option 4). Factor XII, also known as Hageman factor, plays a role in the intrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade. However, its deficiency does not generally lead to bleeding or clotting abnormalities. This is because factor XII deficiency is not associated with significant clinical manifestations or bleeding disorders in most individuals.

Some coagulation factors and the diseases linked with their deficiency are:

   


 

Reference-: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease Edition 10 th Page no 120-122

questions.text:
In an emergency,  complete coagulation pathway is quickly evaluated by:
 1. PT
 2. aPTT
 3. CT
 4. Thromboelastography
questions.solution:
Rapid assessment of entire coagulation pathway in emergency is done by Thromboelastography.

Throboelastography is a technique for evaluating the effectiveness of blood coagulation. Surgery, anesthesiology, emergency rooms, intensive care units, labor and delivery departments are where TEG is most frequently employed.

It evaluates fibrinolysis, clot strength, and platelet function.




Ref- FROM REZAIE, S. REBEL REVIEW #54 THROMBOELASTOGRAM (TEG). HTTP://REBELEM.COM/REBEL-REVIEWS/

questions.text:
What is the most common lung damage finding in COVID 19 infection?
 1. Pulmonary infarction
 2. Diffuse alveolar damage
 3. Endothelial injury
 4. Fibrin clots
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Diffuse alveolar damage
 
  • Diffuse alveolar damage is the most common finding of lung injury in COVID-19 due to ARDS.
  • It is characterized by formation of a hyaline membrane (pink in color) which fully encloses the alveoli.
  • There is associated widespread inflammation and mononuclear cell-dominated alveolar damage.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 1509.

questions.text:
Which of the following is correct about Peutz-Jeghers syndrome?
 A. Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium is most common extra-intestinal manifestation
 B. Arborising pattern 
 C. STK-11 mutation
 D. Autosomal recessive
 E. Multiple GI polyps
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) B, C, E are correct

* Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is one of the polyposis syndromes due to mutation in tumor suppressor gene STK11. It has an autosomal dominant inheritance and is characterized by:

  • multiple hamartomatous polyps, most commonly involving the small intestine (predominantly the jejunum), but also colon and stomach; mouth and esophagus are spared

  • mucocutaneous melanin pigmentation involving the mouth, fingers and toes

* Peutz-Jeghers polyps are non-neoplastic hamartomas due to the proliferation of all three layers of the mucosa, which have a characteristic feature of a smooth muscle core continuous with muscularis mucosa in a tree-like branching pattern.

* Patients are at increased risk of:

  • Intussusception
  • GI tract adenocarcinoma, although the polyps themselves are not premalignant

* Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium is the most common extra-intestinal manifestation of familial adenomatous polyposis coli (FAP) syndrome. 

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 809.

questions.text: What is the least likely cause of bone marrow showing dry tap?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Follicular lymphoma

The least likely cause of Bone marrow showing dry tap amongst the given options is Follicular lymphoma. Dry tap means no cells in Bone Marrow aspiration, then the next line investigation becomes Bone Marrow Biopsy. 
  
* [Extra Edge]:

A nodular or nodular and diffuse growth pattern is observed in involved lymph nodes. Two principal cell types are present in varying proportions:
(1) small cells with irregular or cleaved nuclear contours and scant cytoplasm, referred to as centrocytes (small, cleaved cells), 
(2) larger cells with open nuclear chromatin, several nucleoli, and modest amounts of cytoplasm, referred to as centroblasts


A dry tap on bone marrow is seen usually due to bone marrow fibrosis or in cases of aplastic anemia.

+ Amongst the given options:
- Hairy cell leukemia: dry tap is seen due to perisinusoidal fibrosis, and it shows pancytopenia
- AML M7: Megakaryoblasts release Platelet-derived Growth factor and TGF-Beta which results in none marrow fibrosis
- MDS:  Abnormal dysplastic cells release fibrogenic cytokines which results in bone marrow fibrosis

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 600.

questions.text:
What is the most common cause of JAK2 mutation?
 1. Essential thrombocytosis
 2. Polycythemia Vera
 3. PMF
 4. CLL
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Polycythemia Vera

JAK 2 mutation is most commonly associated with Polycythemia Vera.

JAK 2 mutation is associated with various myeloproliferative disorders, as follows-  
  • i. Chronic myeloid leukemia
  • ii. Polycythemia Vera
  • iii. Essential thrombocythemia
  • iv. Primary myelofibrosis
  • v. Systemic mastocytosis
  • vi. Chronic eosinophilic leukemia

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 625.

choices.text: Anti-CTLA-4 Antibody is being used in the treatment of cancer in advanced stage
Mutation of tumor suppressor genes decreases the antigen toxicity
PD-1 and PD-1L activation leading to tumor suppression
Binding of CD28 leads to immune tolerance

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about immune surveillance is correct
 1. Anti-CTLA-4 Antibody is being used in the treatment of cancer in advanced stage
 2. Mutation of tumor suppressor genes decreases the antigen toxicity
 3. PD-1 and PD-1L activation leading to tumor suppression
 4. Binding of CD28 leads to immune tolerance
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Anti-CTLA-4 Antibody is being used in the treatment of cancer in advanced stage
 
  • Anti CTLA-4 antibody is a new modality, used in treatment of cancers, particularly in advanced stages.
  • Mutation of tumor suppressor gene will increase the antigen toxicity.
  • PD-1 and PD-1L inhibition leads to tumor suppression Binding of CD-28 leads to inhibition of immune tolerance.
  • Binding of CD28 leads to immune tolerance: CD28 binding provides costimulatory signals that promote T cell activation, not tolerance.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 313.

questions.text:
Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis is seen in- 
 A. HIV
 B. SLE
 C. Hepatitis B
 D. CLL
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) All of the above

MPGN is seen in all of the given conditions. MPGN is of two types:

Type 1: Primary MPGN (Idiopathic)
Type 2: Secondary MPGN arising in cases of:
  • i. SLE
  • ii. Endocarditis
  • iv. Infected ventriculoatrial shunts
  • v. Chronic visceral abscesses
  • vi. HIV, Hep B and C infection
  • vii. Schistosomiasis
  • viii. α1-Antitrypsin deficiency
  • ix. Malignant diseases (lymphoid tumors like CLL)
Note: In HIV, FSGS is more common but even MPGN can occur.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2341.

questions.text:
Which is the most likely diagnosis for the given peripheral smear

 1. B 12 deficiency
 2. IDA
 3. HS
 4. MDS
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) B 12 deficiency
 
  • Hypersegmented neutrophils are seen in both Megaloblastic anemia due to B12 deficiency and in Myelodysplastic syndrome. But since vitamin deficiency is much more common it is the better answer.
  • Hypersegmented neutrophils refers to neutrophils with more than 5 nuclear lobules.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 654.

questions.text: The absence of marked Cells will present with all except ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Zollinger Ellison syndrome

The marked structures are Parietal Cells which secrete HCl and Castle's intrinsic factor.

Within the stomach, the most remarkable feature is a marked increase in oxyntic mucosal thickness due to massive parietal cell hyperplasia. Gastrin also induces hyperplasia of mucous neck and endocrine cells within oxyntic mucosa.
In case of Zollinger Ellison syndrome, there is massive parietal cell hyperplasia.

* They are absent in:
  • Vit B12 deficiency
  • Intrinsic factor deficiency
  • Type 1 gastric carcinoid syndrome

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 773.

questions.text:
Rees and Ecker diluting fluid is used in which tube/pipette?
 1. RBC pipettes
 2. WBC pipettes
 3. Wintrobe tube
 4. Westergren tube
questions.solution:
Rees and Ecker diluting fluid is used in RBC pipettes for performing platelet count. 

Note-
  • Hayem's solution is used as RBC diluting fluid  for performing RBC Count. 
  • Turk's fluid is used as WBC diluting fluid while performing WBC count 

Reference: https://ashpublications.org/blood/article/1/6/472/6629/PLATELET-COUNTS-AND-PLATELET-FUNCTION

questions.text:
Which of the following will have pancytopenia, as revealed by a blood test?
A. Megaloblastic anemia
B. Hairy cell leukemia
C. MDS with hypocellular BM
D. APML
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) A, B, C
 
  • Acute Promyelocytic Leukemia doesn’t show pancytopenia. Rather it shows hypercellularity in peripheral smear.
  • Pancytopenia is present in megaloblastic anemia with hypocellular BM as a result of inefficient hematopoiesis.
  • Hairy cell leukemia with hypocellular BM exhibits splenomegaly and pancytopenia from perisinusoidal fibrosis.
  • Pancytopenia and hypocellular BM occur in MDS.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 618.

questions.text: The image below shows a gross illustration of a bone tumor at the lower end of a femur in a 10-year-old child. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Osteosarcoma
 
  • Osteosarcoma is the diagnosis based on the clinical picture given.
  • Giant cell tumor only occurs after growth plate fusion, i.e. after 20-40 years.
  • Osteoblastoma is seen in the diaphyseal region.
  • Chondroblastoma is most commonly seen in elderly population.
  • Also, it is greyish/bluish in color.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1188.

questions.text: A patient presented with meningitis, four-day fever, and erythematous rashes on the chest. There was no previous travel or tick bite history. Increased protein, normal glucose, moderate lymphocytosis and  presence of RBCs were all observed in the CSF. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Enterovirus

Meningitis with CSF parameters of normal glucose, increased protein and lymphocytosis goes in favor of viral meningitis due to enterovirus. 
  • Option A- West Nile virus is endemic in North America but since there is no history of travel, we rule out this option.
  • Option B- Bacterial meningitis will have increased protein and WBC count with predominant neutrophils and decreased CSF glucose levels. Gram staining will show gram positive lanceolate shaped diplococci. 
  • Option C- Meningococcal meningitis will also have increased protein and WBC count with predominant neutrophils and decreased CSF glucose levels. Gram staining will show gram negative diplococci. 
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 351.

questions.text: Prognathism and increased length of hands and feet were present in a male patient. Which of the following gene mutations is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) PIT-1

Mutation of PIT-1 is the likely cause. PIT-1 refers to Pituitary specific transcription factor -1. Its mutation causes:

(1) Gigantism (children)
(2) Acromegaly (adults)
(3) Galactorrhea & amenorrhea
(4) Sexual dysfunction & infertility
(5) Hyperthyroidism

Its mutation is associated with:
  • Somatotroph pituitary adenoma
  • Lactotroph adenoma
  • Thyrotroph adenoma.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2892.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl has freckle-like markings on her face and trunk and a slow-growing, non-tender bulge on the left side of her neck. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Here, 15 year old girl with freckle like spots on face and trunk with slow growing bulge on left side of neck- likely neural tumor is indicative of neurofibromatosis type I. 

Neurofibromatosis Type I aka Von Recklinghausen Disease is an autosomal dominant condition characterized by 

(a) Intellectual disability or seizures
(b) Skeletal defects
(c) Pigmented nodules of the iris ( Lisch nodules )
(d) Cutaneous hyperpigmented macules (café au lait spots)
(e) Neurofibromas
(f) Optic nerve glioma

It is caused by mutations in the NF1 gene, which encodes the tumor suppressor protein neurofibromin and is located at chromosome 17q11.2.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 520.

questions.text: Which of the following is present in the center of target cells
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Haemoglobin
 
  • Codocytes, also known as target cells, are red blood cells that have the appearance of a shooting target with a bullseye.
  • In optical microscopy these cells appear to have a dark center (a central, hemoglobinized area) surrounded by a white ring (an area of relative pallor), followed by dark outer (peripheral) second ring containing a band of hemoglobin.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 647.

questions.text: A patient is suffering from weight gain and lassitude. What could be the cause if tests revealed elevated TSH and low T4?
questions.solution:
Hashimoto’s disease is the possible diagnosis in this scenario.

Increased TSH with low T4 -> Hypothyroidism
  • Graves disease -> Hyperthyroidism (Most common cause)
  • Hashimoto -> Increased TSH with low T4
  • Pituitary adenoma -> TSH secreting adenoma shows increased TSH, T3, T4
  • Hypoparathyroidism ->No increased TSH or low T4

 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2933, 2936.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs promote bone formation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Teriparatide 

Drug that promotes bone formation is Teriparatide.
Drugs promoting bone formation are called anabolic drugs

* [Extra Edge]: Teriparatide
 
  • This recombinant preparation of 1–34 residues of amino terminal of human PTH has been recently introduced for the treatment of severe osteoporosis. It duplicates all the actions of the long (1–84) PTH.
  • Injected s.c. 20 mg once daily, it acts only for 2–3 hours, and has been found to increase bone mineral density in osteoporotic women. The effect was faster and more marked than that produced by estrogens and bisphosphonates (BPNs).
  • Teriparatide is the only agent which stimulates new bone formation, whereas the other two only check bone resorption.
  • In clinical trials it was found to be equally or more effective than estrogens and BPNs in reducing risk of vertebral as well as non-vertebral fractures in osteoporotic women as well as men.
  • Treatment with teriparatide beyond 2 years is not recommended, but BPNs may be continued thereafter. Side effects include dizziness, headache and leg cramps. 
* Other Options are either work by decreasing bone resorption or inhibiting it, no other drug stimulates new bone formation.

* Examples:
  • (a) TERIPARATIDE: a Parathyroid hormone (PTH) analog
  • (b) ABOLAPARATIDE: a PTH receptor peptide analog
  • (c) STRONTIUM RONELATE: anti-osteoporotic agent
  • (d) ROMOSUZUMAB: sclerostin glycoprotein inhibitor

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 365.

choices.text: Can be initiated in minimally motivated person
When used with alcohol, the patient feels drowsiness, chest discomfort and respiratory depression
It’s action persists for 2~3 days after stopping the drug

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Disulfiram is correct
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 3) When used with alcohol, the patient feels drowsiness, chest discomfort and respiratory depression
 
  • Disulfiram used with alcohol causes patient to feel drowsiness, chest discomfort & respiratory depression.
  • Disulfiram is given to highly motivated patients. It is an aversive agent. It inhibits aldehyde dehydrogenase leading to increase in concentration of acetaldehyde which causes: Drowsiness Chest discomfort Respiratory depression.
  • Its action persists for upto 2 weeks after stopping it.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 421.

questions.text: Which of the following antidepressants is the least likely to cause sexual dysfunction?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 2) Mirtazapine
 
  • The antidepressant Mirtazapine causes the least sexual dysfunction.
  • SSRIs cause increase in serotonin that stimulates 5HT-2 receptor present in spinal cord and leads to sexual dysfunction such as erectile dysfunction and anorgasmia.
  • 5HT-2 receptor blockers such as mirtazapine do not have this action and hence, are associated with  decreased sexual side effects.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 490.

choices.text: Should not be used as it is irrational
Can be used as both have a different mechanism of action
Should not be used due to addiction
Can be used to treat cough effectively

questions.text: If dextromethorphan and codeine are being marketed together as an antitussive. How should the combination be handled?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Should not be used as it is irrational

Codeine combined with dextromethorphan as an anti-tussive is an irrational combination.

Codeine and dextromethorphan like central antitussive agents must be combined with:

i. Nasal decongestants
ii. Mucolytic
iii. Expectorant
iv. Paracetamol

Combing two centrally acting antitussive agents have no added advantage so it's an irrational combination. 

These can help to reduce cough effectively.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 239.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in severe COVID treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer Is (Option 3) Favipiravir

Favipiravir is not given in severe COVID, it is given in cases of moderate COVID infection.
In June 2020, favipiravir received the DCGI approval in India for mild and moderate COVID-19 infections.
* Drugs given in sever COVID infection include:
  • i. LMWH
  • ii. Steroids
  • iii. Remdesivir
  • iv. Tocilizumab
Online Reference: 
Agrawal U, Raju R, Udwadia ZF. Favipiravir: A new and emerging antiviral option in COVID-19. Med J Armed Forces India. 2020 Oct;76(4):370-376. doi: 10.1016/j.mjafi.2020.08.004. Epub 2020 Sep 2. PMID: 32895599; PMCID: PMC7467067.

questions.text: An antibiotic was prescribed for a patient who had a fever and a sore throat. Two days later, he appeared with the rash as seen in the picture. Which of the following substances could have caused this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Amoxicillin

Amoxicillin is the antibiotic (β-lactam) causing the presented rash.
Most common side effects of penicillins include allergic reactions in the form of-
  1. Anaphylactic shock
  2. Urticaria, fever, swelling of joints
  3. Skin rashes.
Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 1154.

questions.text: What is the most common drawback of the given device?
questions.solution:
Correct Anwer is (Option 1) Drug deposited in the oropharynx
 
  • The given device is pMDI (Pressurised metered dose inhaler).
  • Most common drawback of pMDI is drug deposition in oropharynx.
  • Gas used is HFA (Hydroxyfluoro-alkaline gas which propels the drug out.
  • Another disadvantage is difficulty in coordinating press with inspiration.
  • Hence, cannot be used in small children without use of spacer. 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 9.

choices.text: TDM is done with penicillin because of narrow therapeutic index
TDM is done with gentamicin because of narrow therapeutic index
TDM is done with both because of dangerous side effects
TDM is done for penicillin as it causes severe anaphylactic reaction

questions.text: Which of the following assertions about a patient receiving a high dose of penicillin and gentamicin is correct?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) TDM is done with gentamicin because of narrow therapeutic index

TDM is done with gentamicin because of the narrow therapeutic index.
A narrow therapeutic index suggests the chances of drug toxicity on even increasing the drug dose slightly is very high, therefore it requires therapeutic drug monitoring for maintaining safety.

* Drugs requiring TDM are- 
  • Digoxin
  • Anti-arrhythmics
  • Theophylline
  • Lithium
  • Aminoglycosides
  • Anti-epileptics
  • TCAs 


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 797.

questions.text: Which of the following are the key issues to address when thinking about releasing a patient who had TCA treatment for a major depressive episode during a 4-week hospital stay
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Suicidal risk
 
  • Suicidal risk is the main concern while considering discharge. In depressed patients after 2-3 weeks of continuous treatment the mood is gradually elevated.
  • The discharge of patient exposes him to the risk of non-compliance which may lead to relapse of depression and the person may commit suicide.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 487.

questions.text: Seizures are being experienced by a patient. Multiple parenchymal cysts are visible on his CT head.  Which of the following statements about management are correct in this case?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in the given clinical scenario is neurocysticercosis caused by larvae of T. Solium. 
 
  • The drug of choice for treatment is albendazole. However, steroids are started before initiating albendazole to reduce the incidence of inflammatory reactions to dead and dying parasitic products. 
 
  • For the treatment of patients with brain parenchymal cysticerci, most authorities favor antiparasitic drugs, including Albendazole (15 mg/kg per day for 8–28 days) and/or praziquantel (50–100 mg/kg daily in three divided doses for 15–30 days). A combination of albendazole and praziquantel (50 mg/kg per day) is more effective in patients with more than two cystic lesions.
 
  • For patients with subarachnoid cysts or giant cysticerci, antiinflammatory medications such as glucocorticoids are needed to reduce arachnoiditis and accompanying vasculitis.
 
  • In patients with diffuse cerebral edema and elevated intracranial pressure due to multiple inflamed lesions, glucocorticoids are the mainstay of therapy, and antiparasitic drugs should be avoided



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1792, 1793.

questions.text: An older woman with migraines who is currently receiving therapy reports recent onset chest pain with no history of angina or MI. Which of the following drugs might have caused this presentation
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) 5HT2 Agonist

Drug 5HT1b/1d agonists like sumatriptan have mechanics of actions causing these presentations.

* 5HT Agonists:
  • Sets off the migraine's vasoconstrictor phase.
  • Takes part in the neurogenic inflammation of the blood vessels
  • Major side effects include Tightness in chest and head, Dizziness, Weakness, Bradycardia, Seizures.
  • Contraindications are Ischemic heart disease, hypertension, epilepsy, hepatic or renal impairment and pregnancy.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 194.

questions.text: A patient who had suffered a pelvic fracture and head injuries was given morphine for pain. As a result, he started having trouble breathing. What might be the reason?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) CO2 retention due to opioid use

CO2 retention due to opioid use is the cause for respiratory difficulty.

* Morphine use in head injury causes:
  • i. Respiratory depression
  • ii. Increases CO2
  • iii. Increases ICT
  • iv. Miosis
Therefore, use of morphine in cases of head injury is contraindicated.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 499.

questions.text:
Which of the following medications are used to treat absence seizures?
A. Carbamazepine
B. Valproate
C. Ethosuximide
D. Gabapentin
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) B and C only
 
  • Valproate and ethosuximide are the drugs used for absence seizures.
  • Most preferred drugs in absence seizures are those which have calcium channel blocking property. 
  • Valproate is used for atypical absence seizure
  • Ethosuximide is used for Typical absence seizure

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 390.

questions.text:
Match the following drugs with their antidotes.
A. Heparin 1. Levocarnitine
B. Ethylene glycol 2. Protamine
C. Hydrofluoric acid 3. Fomepizole
D. Valproate 4. Calcium gluconate
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) A-2, B-3, C-4, D-1

* Drug Effect Antidote:
  • Heparin Excessive Bleeding = Protamine
  • Ethylene glycol Metabolic Acidosis= Fomepizole
  • Hydrofluoric Acid Electrolyte Abnormality = Calcium gluconate
  • Valproate Hyperammonemia = Levocarnitine

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 167.

questions.text:
Match the bacteria to the appropriate drug.
A. Bacteroides 1. Vancomycin
B. MRSA 2. Metronidazole
C. Hemophilus 3. Meropenem
D. Klebsiella 4. Penicillin
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) A-2, B-1, C-4, D-3



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 806.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding the medications used to treat gout is correct
A. Aspirin is not used as it decreases the uric acid secretion
B. Diclofenac is used as it concentrates in the joint
C. Indomethacin is used as it acts by multiple pathways
D. Aspirin is used as it is most powerful NSAID
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Statement A, B & C

Gout results from the precipitation of urate crystals in the tissues and the subsequent inflammatory response. Acute gout usually causes painful distal mono arthritis and can cause joint destruction, subcutaneous deposits (tophi), and renal calculi and damage. In most patients with gout, hyperuricemia arises from underexcretion rather than overproduction of urate.

* The aims of treatment are to:
  • Decrease the symptoms of an acute attack
  • Decrease the risk of recurrent attacks
  • Lower serum urate levels
Statement C Indomethacin is a potent nonselective inhibitor of the COXs. It also inhibits the motility of polymorphonuclear leukocytes, depresses the biosynthesis of mucopolysaccharides, and may have a direct COX-independent vasoconstrictor effect. Indomethacin has prominent anti-inflammatory and analgesic-antipyretic properties like those of the salicylates.
Statement B The drug accumulates in synovial fluid after oral administration, which may explain why its duration of therapeutic effect is considerably longer than its plasma t1/2.
Statement A Aspirin has a bimodal effect on the renal handling of uric acid: High doses of aspirin (>3 g/day) are uricosuric (probably by blocking urate reabsorption), while low dosages (1–2 g/day) cause uric acid retention (probably via inhibiting urate secretion). Low-dose aspirin, indicated for the prophylaxis of cardiovascular events, can cause changes in renal function and uric acid handling in elderly patients.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 33, 842.

questions.text:
Which of the following drugs is associated with a lower risk of death in COVID-19 patients?
A. Dexamethasone
B. Remdesivir
C. Favipiravir
D. HCQ
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Only A
 
  • Dexamethasone is the drug that reduces mortality in COVID- 19 patients.
  • Dexamethasone is a corticosteroid used in a wide range of conditions for its anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressive effects.
  • It was tested in hospitalized patients with COVID-19 and was found to have benefits for critically ill patients.
  • According to preliminary findings shared with WHO (and now available as a preprint), for patients on ventilators, the treatment was shown to reduce mortality by about one third, and for patients requiring only oxygen, mortality was cut by about one fifth.
  • Dexamethasone treatment was associated with reduced risk of in-hospital mortality for n = 1,263 treated, matched 1:3 to untreated, patients not receiving remdesivir and for n = 804 treated, matched 1:1 to untreated, patients receiving remdesivir.
Online Reference: Zhou R, Johnson KE, Rousseau JF, Rathouz PJ; N3C Consortium. Comparative effectiveness of dexamethasone in treatment of hospitalized COVID-19 patients in the United States during the first year of the pandemic: Findings from the National COVID Cohort Collaborative (N3C) data repository. PLoS One. 2024 Mar 21;19(3):e0294892. doi: 10.1371/journal.pone.0294892. PMID: 38512832; PMCID: PMC10956822.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are correct
A. Morphine used in pulmonary oedema
B. Pethidine used in biliary colic
C. Indomethacin is used in headache
D. Aspirin used in peptic ulcer
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) A, B, & C

* Morphine
  • i. Used in pulmonary oedema as it transfers blood from pulmonary to systemic circulation.
  • ii. Used in MI as it decreases preload as well as pain.
  • iii. Decreases sympathetic outflow
  • iv. Contraindicated in biliary colic.
* Pethidine
  • i. Has anticholinergic properties.
  • ii. Used in colicky abdominal pains
  • iii. Relaxes the spasm of biliary sphincter
* Indomethacin
  • i. Preferred for paroxysmal hemicrania
  • ii. Side effect causes frontal headache Aspirin is not used in peptic ulcer cases.
* Aspirin causes peptic ulcer due to COX-1 inhibition-> less prostaglandin production, which act as barrier against gastric acid.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 213.

questions.text:
Which of the following medications will aggravate myasthenia gravis?
A. Lidocaine
B. Meropenem
C. Phenytoin
D. Digene
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) A & D only
 
  • Drugs that will worsen myasthenia gravis are lidocaine and digene.
  • Lidocaine decreases the sensitivity of the postsynaptic membrane to acetylcholine and Antacids like digene may interfere with neuromuscular transmission and hence may lead to worsening of MG.
* Drugs which aggravate myasthenia gravis include:

Aminoglycosides, beta-blockers, LAs, Magnesium (present in digene ), non-depolarizing muscle relaxants and quinine.
 

Here’s a simplified table of drugs to avoid in Myasthenia Gravis along with a mnemonic to remember them:

Drug Class/Example Drugs to Avoid
Aminoglycosides - Gentamicin- Tobramycin
Beta-blockers - Propranolol- Atenolol
Calcium Channel Blockers - Verapamil- Diltiazem
Chloroquine/Hydroxychloroquine - Chloroquine- Hydroxychloroquine
Magnesium Salts - Magnesium sulfate
Quinidine (Antiarrhythmic) - Quinidine
Phenytoin (Anticonvulsant) - Phenytoin
Sedatives (Benzodiazepines) - Diazepam- Lorazepam

Mnemonic: "ABC's Can Cause Myasthenic Problems Quickly"

  • A = Aminoglycosides
  • B = Beta-blockers
  • C = Calcium channel blockers
  • C = Chloroquine/Hydroxychloroquine
  • M = Magnesium salts
  • P = Phenytoin
  • Q = Quinidine
  • S = Sedatives (Benzodiazepines)
Online Reference:
Sheikh S, Alvi U, Soliven B, Rezania K. Drugs That Induce or Cause Deterioration of Myasthenia Gravis: An Update. J Clin Med. 2021 Apr 6;10(7):1537. doi: 10.3390/jcm10071537. PMID: 33917535; PMCID: PMC8038781.

questions.text: A neck lump that was firm but not painful was present in the patient. Upon inspection, it felt warm to the touch and moveable with ease. After a biopsy, molar tooth colonies developed in anaerobic culture in two to three days and revealed gram-positive branching rods when stained. Which medication is ideal for treating this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Penicillin

The most likely diagnosis based on given clinical scenario is Actinomyces.

* Actinomyces features:
  • Strict anaerobes
  • Cause Actinomycosis
  •  Gram-positive and acid-fast negative branching rods
  • Molar tooth colonies on blood agar 
  • Usually presents with painless hard nodule in the neck-seen in most common variety ie cervicofacial. 
  • Drug of choice: Penicillin
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 768.

questions.text:
Which of the following organisms results in a painful glans ulcer?
A. Chlamydia trachomatis
B. Hemophilus dureyi
C. Herpes simplex
D. Neisseria gonorrhea
questions.solution:
Among the given options, painful ulcer on glans penis are seen in genital herpes caused by HSV2>HSV1 and hemophilus ducreyi which causes chancroid.

However, there is painless lymphadenopathy in genital herpes whereas painful lymphadenopathy is seen in chancroid cause by H.ducreyi.

Memorizing Trick: -
Organisms starting with H cause painful genital ulcer 

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 337.

questions.text:

B. Bleeds on touch
C. Painful
D. Groove sign
questions.solution:
Groove sign of Greenblatt is not seen in chancroid, it is seen in LGV.

Chancroids are caused by Haemophilus ducreyi. IP is 1-14 days. Their features include:

i. School of fish/ rail road track appearance on smear examination.
ii. Bleeds on touch (soft sore)
iii. Painful, non-ulcerative ulcer

Drug of choice is azithromycin/ceftriaxone

questions.text: A young man with painful sores as seen in the picture arrives at the STD clinic. What is the most likely microscopic finding of the lesion?
questions.solution:
The microscopic finding of herpes genitalis is multinucleated giant cells.

Pund cells ae seen in Granuloma inguinale.

Henderson Peterson bodies seen in Molluscum contagiosum.

Halberstaedler prowazek bodies  seen in Trachoma

Herpes genitalis is caused by HSV 2 > 1.

Features:
i. Multiple painful vesicles or ulcers with painless lymphadenopathy. 
ii. Non-suppurative
iii. Tzanck smear shows multinucleated giant cells with margination and moulding. 

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 475.

questions.text: What causes affinity maturation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Somatic hypermutation

Affinity maturation is due to somatic hypermutation.
Helper T cells also stimulate the production of antibodies with high affinities for the antigen. This process, called affinity maturation, improves the quality of the humoral immune response.

* [Extra Edge]: Affinity development
i. The process by which B cells create antibodies with higher antigen specificities during an immune response.
ii. Compared to an initial reaction, a secondary response has the potential to produce antibodies with higher affinity.
iii. Takes place in secondary lymphoid organs' germinal centers.
iv. Takes place in 2 interconnected processes:
  • Somatic Hypermutation (SHM), which causes mutations in the immunoglobulin genes variable regions.
  • Clonal Selection in which somatically hypermutated B cells struggle for scarce growth resources, including the presence of antigen.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 203.

questions.text: A disruption of which of the following causes diarrhea in Vibrio cholera?
questions.solution:
Diarrhoea in V. Cholera is due to disruption of zonula occludens.

V. Cholera produces Zona occludens toxins ( apart from usual cholera toxin ), which disrupts the tight junctions between the enterocytes and increases the permeability, this causes leakage of fluid, resulting in diarrhoea.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 282.

questions.text:
Where is galactomannan seen in serum?
A. Invasive aspergillosis
B. Systemic candidiasis
C. Mucormycosis
D. Cryptococcosis
questions.solution:
Galactomannan in serum is seen only in invasive aspergillosis. It is a component of cell wall of Aspergillus and can be detected in serum as well as in bronchoalveolar lavage.

Diagnostic features of invasive aspergillosis-

Positive culture from the affected organ
Detection of galactomannan antigen.
On microscopic examination, narrow acute angle branching septate hyphae
Halo and reverse halo sign on CT.
Drug of choice for invasive aspergillosis is voriconazole.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 613.

questions.text: A patient who had erythematous rashes on the chest and a history of fever for four days came with meningitis. There was no prior travel or tick bite history. His CSF analysis revealed elevated protein, normal glucose, mild lymphocytosis, and few RBCs. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Enterovirus

CSF shows elevated proteins and normal glucose with mild lymphocytosis which is indicative of viral infection. Since there is no prior history of travel, the west nile virus is ruled out.



Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 677.

questions.text: Which pneumonia is caused by a catalase and oxidase positive, gram negative, pleomorphic bacillus growing on chocolate agar?
questions.solution:
H.influenza is  gram negative pleomorphic bacillus growing on chocolate agar which causes pneumonia in younger age group. 

H. Influenzae:

i. Gram negative pleomorphic bacillus
ii. Grows on chocolate agar
iii. Is catalase and oxidase positive
iv. Causes pneumonia, meningitis, croup, suppurative lesions, bronchitis
v. Fildes' agar is best for primary isolation of Haemophilus species.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 333.

questions.text: The graphic depicts the organism that causes microcephaly being transmitted through the placenta. Identify the most likely organism.
questions.solution:

questions.text: Which of the following diseases, once clinically evident, has the highest fatality rate?
questions.solution:
Highest mortality is seen with Rabies once clinically manifested.

Case fatality rate refers to the number of cases which died due to the disease divided by the total number of cases. It is the indicator used to measure mortality of any disease.

Case fatality rates in different diseases:

A. Zika : 10-20%
B. Ebola : 20-80%
C. Rabies : 100%
D. Nipah : 50-80%

Death is certain once rabies has manifested.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 542.

questions.text: A patient in his 30s shows in with urethral discharge. Below is a photo of a gram stain. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Neisseria gonorrhoea is the probable cause of urethral discharge with the given histology as intracytoplasmic diplococci could be seen.

N. Gonorrhea features- 

i. Gram-negative aerobic,
ii. non-sporulating, non-motile
iii. oxidase-positive cocci arranged typically in pairs (diplococci).
iv. Cultured in Stuart's transport medium, chocolate agar or Mueller-Hinton agar, Thayer-Martin medium.
v. Disease acquired by sexual contact.

Drug of choice for treatment of gonococcal urethritis is combination of azithromycin and ceftriaxone. 

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 234.

questions.text:
A 13-year-old girl has allegedly been raped. Parents brought the female to the hospital, but they are refusing to let a doctor to examine her. What should the doctor do next
i. Inform police
ii. Collect the swabs
iii. Document the refusal

v. Treatment should be provided without consent of the parents
questions.solution:
The Doctor should -

questions.text: Identify the image given below:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1. Marbling

The given image shows Marbling.
Marbling of Skin refers to the mosaic like pattern on the skin which is seen at vein coverage due to production of H2S gas by the bacteria which combines with Hb present in the blood to form a greenish blue compound called Sulf-met-hemoglobin. It is usually seen ~ 36 hours since death.

questions.text:
Correct statement about fresh water drowning is: 
a. Hemodilution
b.Hyperkalemia
c.Hyponatremia
d.Arrhythmia
questions.solution:
All of the given options are correct about fresh water drowning.

In case of fresh water drowning, the water which fills the lungs is hypotonic compared to blood. This causes dilution of the plasma leading to hemodilution, hyponatremia and  swelling of RBCs and further their lysis.

This lysis causes release of potassium present within the RBCs into the plasma causing hyperkalemia, which leads to arrythmias.



Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 366.

questions.text: What is the most likely reason for death for a 22-year-old female with bleeding in her eyes and neck bruising?
questions.solution:
The most likely cause of death, based on the facts in the inquiry and the provided photographs, could be throttling.

There will be ligature marks in the neck region in the event of hanging or ligature strangling. There is no ligature mark visible in this instance.

Hemorrhage in eyes are associated with cases of throttling and not drowning.

Manual Strangulation/Throttling: It is a type of strangulation where bare hands are used to compress the neck and strangulate. Cause of death is Asphyxia.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 353.

questions.text: The medial end of the clavicle and the body segment of the sternum are fused in the X-ray image presented. What is the likely age of the person
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4. > 25yrs
  • Approximate age of the person with fused medial end of clavicle and body of sternum will be most likely > 25 years. Medial end of clavicle is completely fused by 21-22 years of age. Medial end of clavicle fuses with sternum at 22 years in males and 20 in females.
  • The sternum is formed by fusion of manubirum, 4 sternebrae and xiphoid process. The fusion of sternebrae occurs from below upwards followed by its fusion to xiphoid process and then fusion of manubrium to the fused sternum. 1st and 2nd sternebrae- 25 years 2nd and 3rd sternebrae- 20 years 3rd and 4th sternebrae- 15 years Xiphoid process with body- 40-45 years Manubrium with rest of sternum- 60 years.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 34th Edition, Page No 77.

questions.text:
In relation to the KF Ring, what is true?
A. Pathognomic of Wilson’s Disease
B. Seen in superior and inferior Descemet’s Membrane
C. Seen in all patients with Neurological involvement
D. Seen in all patients with hepatic involvement
E. Disappears with Desferrioxamine
questions.solution:
True statements are:
Statement B: KF ring is seen in the superior and inferior Descemet’s membrane.
Statement C: Seen in all patients with neurological involvement. KF ring is seen in >95% patients of Wilson’s disease with Neurological involvement.

Incorrect statements:
A: Along with Wilson’s diseases, KF ring is also seen in: Primary biliary cholangitis (PBC), Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC), Cholestasis etc.
D: KF ring is associated with around 65% of those with hepatic involvement.
E: They disappear on treating with copper chelating agents like D-penicillamine and may reappear with progression of the disease.
Desferrioxamine is an iron chelating agent




Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2549, 2615, 3236, 3237.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about POAG is correct?
A. The blockage at the level of TM is seen on gonioscopy
B. First degree relatives are at 1% more risk of developing POAG
C. On dilating the pupil, IOP always rises
D. Visual Field Defect can be therein the normal C:D ratio
E. Family members are having more chances of developing steroid responsiveness
questions.solution:
The true statements for POAG are D and E.

Statement D:
- A deficiency in the retinal nerve fiber layer (RNFL) may be the source of visual field defects.
- RNFL defect is a precursor to chronic optic neuritis, and the initial Cup: Disc ratio is normal.

Statement E:
- Patients with POAG and their offspring and siblings are more likely steroid responders ie they respond to 6 weeks topical steroid therapy with a significant rise of IOP.

Other statements:

Statement A- Inability to visualize the normal trabecular meshwork on gonioscopy is seen in primary angle closure glaucoma.

Statement B-Siblings are at 10% increased risk of developing POAG where offspring are at 4% increased risk.

Statement C- Primary angle closure glaucoma is associated with exacerbation of IOP with pupillary dilatation and not POAG.



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1115.
Parsons' Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 266, 270.
Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 236.
Kanski's Clinical Ophthalmology, 8th edition, Page no 349.

questions.text: For the diagnosis of a fixed dilated pupil, which of the following is used
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Pilocarpine 0.1%

Anisocoria which increases in light is differentiated on the basis of “Ocular mobility” and “Pilocarpine test”.
  • On application of Pilocarpine 0.125%, pupils constrict in Holme’s Adie’s tonic pupil. In cases of Holme’s Adie’s tonic pupil/ fixed dilated pupil, constriction is seen with Pilocarpine 0.1%. 
  • In case of no constriction, Pilocarpine 1% is added: Constriction implies 3rd nerve palsy whereas No constriction implies Pharmacological mydriasis. 
Note- Cocaine test ( 2-4% ) is performed in Horner's syndrome in which small pupils fail to dilate on instillation of cocaine.



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 965, 966.

choices.text: Reducing IOP is effective in delaying the incidence of POAG

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect in relation to the progression of ocular hypertension in POAG?
questions.solution:
Primary open angle glaucoma risk factors include family history. Gene mutations of WDR 36, optineurin, Myo C are implicated in POAG. 

High risk factors for the progression of ocular hypertension to POAG:

1. Ageing- as age increases risk also increase
2. Raised IOP- > 30 mmHg; reducing IOP delays incidence of POAG
3. Central Corneal Thickness- < 550 microns
4. Disc ratio- Increased Cup:Disc ratio> 0.7 (normal- 0.3-0.4)
5. Splinter hemorrhages
6. Pattern standard deviation in Humphrey’s analyzer

questions.text:
A child receiving therapy for steroid-dependent nephrotic syndrome is brought to the OPD for immunization.

A. All live vaccines under NIS can be given
B. All killed vaccines under NIS can be given
C. Only pneumococcal vaccines should be given to this child
D. Oral polio vaccine is avoided in the child’s sibling
questions.solution:
In a child with Nephrotic syndrome who is on chronic steroid intake - since the child is immunocompromised -Live vaccines are contraindicated and the Oral polio vaccine must be avoided in the child’s siblings because
  • OPV is a live vaccine and it can be shed in the stools and contact with the contaminated things can cause polio to the immunosuppressed child.
  • All killed vaccines under NIS, however, can be given.
The statement ( C) is incorrect as it is the not only vaccine which can be given ,others vaccines can also be given in immunocompromised child.
Hence, statements B and D are correct statements.

questions.text: You work as a PHC medical officer. Which of the following regimens would you recommend for mass anaemia prophylaxis
questions.solution:
Ferrous sulfate and folic acid is advisable to be given for mass prophylaxis of anemia.

Option (1) is most appropriate answer.


Anemia prophylaxis refers to measures taken to prevent anemia, especially in populations at higher risk, such as pregnant women, young children, and individuals with chronic illnesses.

Nutritional Interventions:

  • Iron Supplementation: Providing iron supplements to at-risk groups, particularly pregnant women and children.
  • Folic Acid: Ensuring adequate intake of folic acid, which is essential for red blood cell formation.
  • Vitamin B12: Monitoring and supplementing vitamin B12, particularly in populations at risk of deficiency.

questions.text: Which of the following has the highest death rate after clinical manifestation?
questions.solution:
• Rabies has the highest death rate after clinical manifestation. Once clinical symptoms of rabies appear, the disease is almost universally fatal. Despite the availability of a vaccine and post-exposure prophylaxis, untreated rabies leads to death in nearly 100% of cases after symptoms develop.
  • Ebola: While Ebola has a high mortality rate (ranging from 25% to 90%, depending on the outbreak and healthcare availability), it is not as uniformly fatal as rabies after clinical symptoms appear.
 
  • Nipah: Nipah virus infection also has a high mortality rate, which can range from 40% to 75%, but it is still not as high as rabies after symptoms manifest.
 
  • Zika: Zika virus typically causes mild illness, and the death rate associated with Zika is very low compared to the other viruses listed.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 322.

questions.text:

questions.text: In the image below, the patient is in the following position:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Reverse Trendelenburg position

The image given in the question is that of the Reverse Trendelenburg position as head is elevated.
Reverse Trendelenburg position: Used in Upper Abdominal surgeries like Lap Cholecystectomy, surgeries of head and neck. 

+ Objectives of correct surgical positioning:

● Facilitate safe anaesthesia and surgery
● Reduce adverse physiological insults
● Optimise surgical exposure and ergonomics
● Maintain patient’s dignity by avoiding unnecessary exposure

* [Extra Edge]: Supine position in OT table


This is the most common position for general surgical procedures. The patient’s arms may be placed by their side or extended to afford access to intravenous and arterial cannula. This is a versatile position and can be modified as follows:

● Rose’s position: slight neck extension for head and neck surgery.
● Shoulder and arm extended: to assist in axillary and breast surgery.
● Trendelenburg position: the head end of the table is tilted down on an incline with the patient’s knees slightly flexed. This is often used in pelvic procedures and when resuscitating a patient in shock.
● Reverse Trendelenburg position: the head end of the table is tilted up, thereby placing the head higher than the feet.

+ In advanced laparoscopic surgery, exaggerated and frequent position changes during the course of the operation are used to enhance surgical exposure. An excellent example would be in laparoscopic resection of the rectum, wherein the table is tilted to the right to aid in left colon mobilisation; a neutral or reverse Trendelenburg position is used to mobilise the transverse colon; and pelvic dissection is completed with a steep Trendelenburg position. This can only be achieved if the patient is well positioned and secured.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 96.

questions.text: 5 days after having a lap cholecystectomy, a patient complained of pain in right upper quadrant. On USG, a 5 cm collection is visible in Morrison's pouch. Biliary leakage may be a possibility. What kind of investigation is most accurate at finding the leak
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1. ERCP
 

After a laparoscopic cholecystectomy, the presence of a fluid collection in Morrison's pouch (the space between the liver and the right kidney) along with pain suggests the possibility of a biliary leak. A biliary leak can occur due to injury to the bile ducts during the surgery, and this requires accurate diagnosis and management.

Here's a breakdown of the options:

  1. ERCP (Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography):
    ERCP is the most accurate investigation for diagnosing a biliary leak. It allows for direct visualization of the bile ducts and can identify the location and cause of a leak. Additionally, ERCP has the advantage of being therapeutic: if a leak is found, it can be treated simultaneously by placing a biliary stent to divert bile flow and allow the leak to heal.

  2. HIDA (Hepatobiliary Iminodiacetic Acid scan):
    HIDA is a nuclear medicine scan that is used to assess the function of the gallbladder and bile ducts. It is helpful for detecting biliary leaks but is not as specific as ERCP for locating the exact site of the leak. It works by tracing the flow of a radiolabeled bile acid, and if a leak is present, the radiotracer will appear in abnormal locations (such as the peritoneal cavity). While useful, it is not as definitive as ERCP.

  3. MRCP (Magnetic Resonance Cholangiopancreatography):
    MRCP is a non-invasive imaging technique that uses MRI to visualize the biliary tree. It is very effective at detecting bile duct injuries and can provide clear images of the biliary system. While it is an excellent diagnostic tool, ERCP is more commonly used for both diagnosing and treating a biliary leak, as MRCP cannot provide the same level of therapeutic intervention.

  4. CECT (Contrast-Enhanced Computed Tomography):
    CECT is useful for identifying collections or abscesses and can help detect fluid collections like those in Morrison's pouch. However, it is not the most accurate for identifying biliary leaks. CECT can suggest a leak if it shows a bile-containing collection, but it cannot definitively demonstrate the leak's source. Therefore, it is not as specific as ERCP or MRCP.

Conclusion:

ERCP (option 1) is the most accurate investigation for diagnosing a biliary leak and also has therapeutic value, making it the best choice for managing a potential biliary leak after laparoscopic cholecystectomy.

questions.text: A young man came in complaining of recurring calf pain. Upon examination, a sore ulcer at the big toe is seen, which is encircled by discoloured skin. Which of the options below would be the most effective as a first step in this case?

Investigation for PVD:
 
  1. Initial : Duplex Scan
  2. IOC : CT angiography
  3. Best investigation : Digital Subtraction Angiography.
Duplex scan is non-invasive and relatively inexpensive, hence is used as an initial investigation. It combines both traditional and doppler ultrasound.

questions.text: An abdominal ache had been present for several days in a 45-year-old patient with known peptic ulcer disease. He has been complaining of abdominal distension and escalating pain for the past two hours. This image was obtained using an X-ray. What is the next course of action?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2. IV fluids and emergency laparotomy
 
  • The given history along with the presence of air under the diaphragm as seen in the X-Ray are suggestive of perforation causing pneumoperitoneum which might have occurred as a complication of peptic ulcer causing perforation in the gastric wall.
  • The next step in management should be iv fluids and emergency laparotomy.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man who is having increasing trouble swallowing both food and liquids is put through a barium study. The image is seen here. What is the next stage in the patient's care?
questions.solution:
Correct Option  is 1. Upper G.I Endoscopy + Manometry

Taking into consideration the age, symptoms, history and the X-ray which shows Bird-Beak appearance, the most probable diagnosis is Achalasia Cardia.

It is characterized by failure of organized esophageal peristalsis, which results in food stasis and frequently noticeable esophageal dilatation and poor relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter due to damage to the Auerbach plexus and vagus nerve. 

To look for constrictions and other causes of Achalasia cardia plus for confirming the diagnosis, we do upper GI endoscopy with Manometry (which shows pressure at the level of Gastro-esophageal junction).

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1122.

questions.text: A young boy who had had RTA was brought to the emergency department. He is unresponsive. His ICT is elevated, and his Glasgow coma scale is low ( E2 V2 M3 ). Imaging of the brain and spine using NCCT is normal. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history given in the question corresponds to Diffuse Axonal Injury.

* Diffuse Axonal Injury :
  • It is the most common type of traumatic brain injury
  • It occurs when the brain changes its position quickly within the skull and sustains damage as a result.
  • As the brain rapidly accelerates and decelerates inside the hard bone of the skull, axons are severed.
Symptoms :
  • Unconsciousness
  • Disorientation
  • Headache
  • Nausea and Vomiting
Investigations :
  • Early : NCCT
  • MRI- IOC
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 368.

questions.text: What is the most common lung finding in COVID-19?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Diffuse Alveolar Damage
 
  • Diffuse alveolar damage is a type of lung injury that is characterized by widespread inflammation and damage to the alveoli. It is the most common lung finding in COVID-19.
 
  • In COVID-19, the virus can directly damage the alveoli, or it can cause an immune response that leads to damage to the alveoli. The damage to the alveoli can lead to fluid accumulation in the lungs, which can make it difficult to breathe.
 
  • Other lung findings that can be seen in COVID-19 include:
    • Ground-glass opacities
    • Consolidation
    • Pleural effusion


Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 353.

questions.text: Which of the following will produce painful ulcers on the glans tip
questions.solution:
• Chancroid presents with a painful genital ulcer and tender inguinal lymphadenopathy.
  • It is caused by the bacterium Haemophilus ducreyi.
  • Can have single or multiple ulcers.
  • The incubation period is 3-10 days.
  • The primary lesion begins as a painful papule that undergoes central necrosis to form painful, non-indurated ulcers with undermined edges.
  • Kissing ulcers due to autoinoculation may also be present.
  • It is associated with painful lymphadenopathy, which later progresses to form suppurating buboes and sinuses.
  • Other options: Herpes genitalis is characterized by painful vesicular lesions that progress to ulcers in the genital region, caused by the herpes simplex virus (HSV). U=Multiple ulcers are seen. It is usually associated with localized tender lymphadenopathy. LGV will present will painless ulcers. Gonorrhea would not usually present with ulcers.

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 30.21

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient complaining of having persistent feelings that his hands are dirty even though they are not visits the psychiatry OPD. He is aware that these are merely his thoughts. He feels discomfort from this, so he has to wash them time and time again. This is a mental disease of:
questions.solution:
• Obsessive-compulsive disorder is a disorder of possession of thought.
  • Obsessions are thoughts that cause stress and compulsions are actions taken to counter that stress.
  • Controversial: Fish's Clinical Psychopathology describes obsession as a disorder of possession of thought. Whereas, Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry (11th edition) list it under disorder of content of thought.
  • AIIMS follows Fish's Clinical Psychopathology as a Standard reference book - hence for INICET- Obessesion is disorder of the possession of thought.

questions.text: A male patient recently lost his work (1 week ago), which caused him to become agitated and depressed. His mood got worse when he pondered about his employment and the future. He was more irritable around the people in his house, but on occasion, he went to the movies with his friends and was able to enjoy himself. What can be the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The patient is most probably suffering from Adjustment disorder.
  • Since depression is persistent, it can be ruled out in this instance because the patient is able to have fun.
  • The symptoms of generalized anxiety disorder must last for at least six months.
  • Adjustment disorder Occurs when a person has a great amount of trouble coping with major psychosocial stressors.
  • Typically, symptoms start 2 weeks to 3 months after the incident and go away within 6 months.

questions.text: What is the appropriate medical management for a psychotic patient who developed voluntary, meaningless movements and was once seen standing stationary for hours with waxy flexibility?

  • A behavioral disorder and psycho-motor immobility.

questions.text: Which of the following distinguishes Alzheimer's disease-related delirium from dementia
questions.solution:
• Delirium refers to presence of altered level of consciousness with cognitive impairment with sudden and acute onset.
  • Dementia stands for loss of cognitive functions in clear consciousness which is a chronic condition.
 
  • Delirium and dementia can be differentiated by the memory disturbance feature; memory disturbance is seen in dementia and not seen in delirium.

questions.text: TCA was administered to a patient in the hospital for 4 weeks in order to treat a serious depressive episode. Which of the following are your primary worries while thinking about his discharge

Correct Option is 1: SUICIDAL RISK

  • Suicidal behaviours are common side effects of Tricyclic Antidepressants (TCA) because the energy level rises with administration of antidepressants, thus attempting suicide can increase which is the paradox, and thus the attendants should be warned about this while planning to discharge the patient.

questions.text: Which antidepressant is least likely to cause sexual dysfunction, out of the following
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Mirtazapine
