questions.text:
What test is not frequently used to diagnose osteoporosis?
A. DEXA
B. Bone scan
C. Quantitative CT
D. Chemical analysis
E. X-ray
questions.solution:
Investigations of Osteoporosis:
X-Ray
Chemical analysis : Ca, phosphate, alkaline phosphatase, plasma albumin are checked.
DEXA scan : it is X ray based bone densitometry - Gold standard.
Neutron activation analysis.
Bone biopsy
Quantitative CT Scan.

Bone scan is not commonly used in osteoporosis - it is used to detect the osteoblastic activity in bone.
Frequently used to diagnose osteoporosis- X Ray, DEXA scan and chemical analysis. Hence best ans is B and C. 


Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 309

questions.text: What is the IOC for osteoporosis diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry (DEXA or DXA) is a technique used to aid in the diagnosis of osteopenia and osteoporosis. 
 

Values are calculated for the lumbar vertebrae and femur preferentially.

Bone mineral density (BMD) is calculated in g/cm2, and then compared against two reference population giving two scores. 

  • T-score: comparison by standard deviation (SD) to a young adult population, matched for sex and ethnicity (used for postmenopausal women and men >50 years) and classified by WHO criteria 4
    • ≥-1.0: normal
    • <-1.0 to >-2.5: osteopenia
    • ≤-2.5: osteoporosis
    • ≤-2.5 plus fragility fracture: severe osteoporosis

Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 309

questions.text: Which of the following medications encourages the production of bones?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Teriparatide

Drug that promotes bone formation is Teriparatide.
Drugs promoting bone formation are called anabolic drugs

* [Extra Edge]: Teriparatide
 
  • This recombinant preparation of 1–34 residues of amino terminal of human PTH has been recently introduced for the treatment of severe osteoporosis. It duplicates all the actions of the long (1–84) PTH.
  • Injected s.c. 20 mg once daily, it acts only for 2–3 hours, and has been found to increase bone mineral density in osteoporotic women. The effect was faster and more marked than that produced by estrogens and bisphosphonates (BPNs).
  • Teriparatide is the only agent which stimulates new bone formation, whereas the other two only check bone resorption.
  • In clinical trials it was found to be equally or more effective than estrogens and BPNs in reducing risk of vertebral as well as non-vertebral fractures in osteoporotic women as well as men.
  • Treatment with teriparatide beyond 2 years is not recommended, but BPNs may be continued thereafter. Side effects include dizziness, headache and leg cramps. 
* Other Options are either work by decreasing bone resorption or inhibiting it, no other drug stimulates new bone formation.

* Examples:
  • (a) TERIPARATIDE: a Parathyroid hormone (PTH) analog
  • (b) ABOLAPARATIDE: a PTH receptor peptide analog
  • (c) STRONTIUM RONELATE: anti-osteoporotic agent
  • (d) ROMOSUZUMAB: sclerostin glycoprotein inhibitor

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 365.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient is dizzy and has had palpitations for two hours. When being admitted, SBP was 70 mmHg. A quick ECG reveals narrow complex tachycardia. Which statement about how this case should be handled is accurate?
questions.solution:
From the information in the question, most probable diagnosis is PSVT.
 
  • In case of hemodynamically unstable patient, QRS synchronous Direct Current Cardioversion should be done.
  • Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia is characterised by bursts of faster-than-normal heart rate.
  • Most prevalent from the second to the fourth decade of life Women > Men ( in case of AVNRT )

Most of the time it's tolerated well, however in older people it may cause:

i. Angina
ii. Pulmonary edema
iii. Hypotension
iv. Syncope

questions.text: What is the most critical manifestation of CKD?
questions.solution:
Hyperkalemia is is the most critical manifestation of Chronic kidney disease.
  • It may lead to life threatening cardiac arrythmia and Diastolic arrest.
  • K+ >5.0 mEq/L
  • Acute reduction is required at levels >7.0 mEq/L
  • ECG - Tall peaked T waves

TREATMENT:
 
i. IV Calcium - most rapid and effective way to antagonize myocardial toxic effect
ii. IV Insulin
iii. Beta2 adrenergic agonist
iv. Hemodialysis if hyperkalemia is persistent or severe




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2313, 2316.

questions.text: Patient of middle age has had chest pain for the last three hours. Trop T = 14 ng/dl, patient's ECG demonstrates ST segment depression and T wave inversion. Vitals remain constant. Which course of treatment is recommended for this patient
questions.solution:
The patient is suffering from NSTEMI (Non-ST elevation MI). Aspirin with heparin can be used for the initial treatment for this patient. PCI is done in critically unstable and high risk patients. 

Acute coronary syndrome is divided into two main groups: 

1. ST-segment Elevation Myocardial Infarction (STEMI)
2. Non-ST-Elevation Acute Coronary Syndrome (NSTE-ACS)

NSTE-ACS is further categorized into:

- NSTEMI (where myocyte necrosis is present and cardiac troponins are elevated)
- Unstable Angina (where myocyte necrosis is absent and cardiac troponins are not elevated)

The diagnosis of NSTE-ACS relies on the following criteria:

- Severe chest discomfort accompanied by at least one of these three features:
  - Occurrence at rest or with minimal exertion, lasting more than 10 minutes
  - Recent onset
  - Crescendo pattern

Additionally, the ECG may show:
- ST segment depression
- T wave inversion
- Elevated cardiac troponins in the case of NSTEMI.

Management of NSTE-ACS:
 
  • To alleviate pain and discomfort, the initial treatment includes bed rest, nitrates, beta blockers, and inhaled oxygen (administered only if arterial oxygen saturation is below 90%).
  • Antithrombotic therapy involves both antiplatelet and anticoagulant medications:
- Dual Antiplatelet Therapy (DAPT): Aspirin (162-325 mg) plus one ADP receptor inhibitor (Ticagrelor, Clopidogrel, or Prasugrel).
- Anticoagulation: Options include Enoxaparin, unfractionated heparin, Fondaparinux, or Bivalirudin.
 
  • An early invasive strategy is recommended for stabilized patients at high risk for coronary events (based on TIMI, GRACE, or HEART scores). This includes diagnostic coronary angiography within 2-72 hours of presentation, followed by revascularization (either percutaneous coronary intervention or coronary artery bypass grafting).


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2047, 2051.

b. Idiopathic Pulmonary fibrosis

questions.text: 40-year-old smoker presents with chronic cough, dyspnea, and chest pain for the past two years. His HRCT chest is displayed below. What is the likely diagnosis?

questions.text:
A dengue patient who was admitted hasn't had pyrexia in the past 24 hours and has a healthy appetite. His blood pressure is 110/70 millimeters of mercury. Hematocrit is 44%, TLC is 4K, and platelet count is 34K according to the workup. When he blows his nose, he experiences epistaxis, which has since resolved on its own. What is the best course of action to take next for this patient's care
a. IVF
b. 4 units of platelet-rich plasma
c. Reassurance and observation
d. Plenty of oral fluids
questions.solution:
Reassurance and observation with plenty of oral fluids is the next step in management.

Intravenous fluids should be reduced or discontinued when any of the following signs are present:
• Normal blood pressure, pulse and peripheral perfusion;
• Decrease in hematocrit
• Apyrexia (without the use of antipyretics) for more than 24–48 hours;
• Resolving bowel/abdominal symptoms;
• Improving urine output.

Continuing intravenous fluid therapy beyond the 48 hours of the critical phase will put the patient at risk of pulmonary oedema and other complications such as thrombophlebitis.

Indications for Platelet transfusion: 
  1. Prophylactic platelet transfusion may be given at level of <10,000/cu.mm
  2. Prolonged shock; with coagulopathy and abnormal coagulogram
  3. Spontaneous bleeding manifestations                                                                                                                                                            In case of systemic massive bleeding platelet transfusion may be needed in addition to red cell transfusion.



Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 296.
National Guidelines for Clinical Management of Dengue Fever 2023, MoHFW, Govt of India. URL: https://ncvbdc.mohfw.gov.in/Doc/National Guidelines for Clinical Management of Dengue Fever 2023.pdf

40 yr female presents with abdominal pain and gross distension. Vitals are stable. P/A findings shows presence of dullness in flanks ?

ii. Minimum amount of fluid should be 500ml to show shifting dullness in flanks

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient was admitted with severe ascites and had an abdominal paracentesis. SAAG = S. albumin - Ascitic fluid albumin = 3.5-1.2= 2.3 gm%.

choices.text: Complete steroids course and then give anti parasite agents

questions.text: A 35-year-old man has been experiencing headaches for the past two months and had a seizure a day ago. AED was started, and the patient is stable. A head MRI reveals several calcified lesions in the parietal lobe as well as cystic lesions with scolex and perilesional edoema. Which statement concerning how this case should be handled is true
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in the given clinical scenario is neurocysticercosis caused by larvae of T. Solium. 
 
  • The drug of choice for treatment is albendazole. However, steroids are started before initiating albendazole to reduce the incidence of inflammatory reactions to dead and dying parasitic products. 
 
  • For the treatment of patients with brain parenchymal cysticerci, most authorities favor antiparasitic drugs, including Albendazole (15 mg/kg per day for 8–28 days) and/or praziquantel (50–100 mg/kg daily in three divided doses for 15–30 days). A combination of albendazole and praziquantel (50 mg/kg per day) is more effective in patients with more than two cystic lesions.
 
  • For patients with subarachnoid cysts or giant cysticerci, antiinflammatory medications such as glucocorticoids are needed to reduce arachnoiditis and accompanying vasculitis.
 
  • In patients with diffuse cerebral edema and elevated intracranial pressure due to multiple inflamed lesions, glucocorticoids are the mainstay of therapy, and antiparasitic drugs should be avoided



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1792, 1793.

questions.text: Find the surgical position in the illustration.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Reverse trendelenburg position

The image given in the question is that of the Reverse Trendelenburg position as head is elevated.
+ Reverse Trendelenburg position:
  • Used in Upper Abdominal surgeries like Lap Cholecystectomy.
  • Used in surgery of head and neck.
  • Used to improve exposure of prostate during surgery.
+ Objectives of correct surgical positioning:

● Facilitate safe anaesthesia and surgery
● Reduce adverse physiological insults
● Optimise surgical exposure and ergonomics
● Maintain patient’s dignity by avoiding unnecessary exposure

* [Extra Edge]: Supine position in OT table


This is the most common position for general surgical procedures. The patient’s arms may be placed by their side or extended to afford access to intravenous and arterial cannula. This is a versatile position and can be modified as follows:

● Rose’s position: slight neck extension for head and neck surgery.
● Shoulder and arm extended: to assist in axillary and breast surgery.
● Trendelenburg position: the head end of the table is tilted down on an incline with the patient’s knees slightly flexed. This is often used in pelvic procedures and when resuscitating a patient in shock.
● Reverse Trendelenburg position: the head end of the table is tilted up, thereby placing the head higher than the feet.

+ In advanced laparoscopic surgery, exaggerated and frequent position changes during the course of the operation are used to enhance surgical exposure. An excellent example would be in laparoscopic resection of the rectum, wherein the table is tilted to the right to aid in left colon mobilisation; a neutral or reverse Trendelenburg position is used to mobilise the transverse colon; and pelvic dissection is completed with a steep Trendelenburg position. This can only be achieved if the patient is well positioned and secured.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 96.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old IHD patient presents with abrupt, severe, generalised stomach discomfort and frequent vomiting attacks.
His heartbeat is 118 bpm, his rhythm is abnormally erratic, and his blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg. Bowel noises are not present, and the abdomen appears mushy. In this situation, which of the following could be a likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3. Acute mesenteric ischemia

Acute mesenteric ischemia is a potential diagnosis when the rhythm is erratic, the belly is soft (guarding is not seen in this picture), and vomiting episodes are frequent.
 
  • Acute pancreatitis -> No features suggestive of pancreatitis. No history of pain abdomen radiating to back.
  • Ruptured aortic aneurysm -> Pulsation abdominal lump as a feature not present
  • Peptic ulcer perforation ->No history suggestive of Peritonitis or history of analgesic intake or guarding and rigidity
Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 928.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female complained of a lump and edema in the left breast for the last 15 days. Upon inspection, it was mobile over the chest wall and was associated with the increased temperature of the local site. What is the likely diagnosis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Inflammatory Ca

The left breast's recent 15-day swelling and the increase in local temperature are signs of inflammatory breast cancer.
Inflammatory breast cancer:
i. A short-lived, rapidly progressing tumour
ii. Warm, painful, and diffuse
iii. Involving the entire breast tissue and extending to the skin of the chest wall with the appearance of peau d' orange.
iv. The affected area covers more than 1/3 of the breast skin.
v. Widespread lymphedema brought on by tumour emboli in cutaneous lymphatics.

According to AJCC 8th Edition 
T4d Inflammatory carcinoma; peau d’orange and redness involving >1/3rd of the surface of the breast with or without a breast lump




Fig: Diffuse redness (erythema) and skin oedema involving more than one-third of the breast, with an enlarged left breast – features of inflammatory carcinoma.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 932.

ii. Altered mental status

questions.text:
Which of the following is true when a child is diagnosed with congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis?
A. Bilious vomiting
B. Visible peristalsis
C. Hypochloremia and hypokalemia
D. Palpable abdominal mass
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4. B, C & D​​​​​​​

Metabolic abnormality with palpable abdominal mass, visible peristalsis from left to right is seen in hypertrophic pyloric stenosis.

Clinical features of pyloric stenosis
  • Seen during the third and sixth weeks of life.
  • Forceful, projectile, and non-bilious vomiting
  • Presence of visible gastric peristalsis (VGP) from left to rifgt
  • Palpable lump of hypertrophied pylorus- from the left side, a movable, smooth, firm, olive-like mass with all borders well defined, moves with respiration, and has poor resonance on percussion.
  • Constipation
  • Dehydration and weight loss
  • Hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis and electrolyte imbalance.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 259.

questions.text:
A 4 cm by 3 cm irregular mass that is neither fixed to the skin nor the chest wall is seen in the right upper quadrant of the right breast in a 50-year-old woman's patient. A 2 cm lymph node is felt in the right axilla. The opposite breast felt completely normal. Which of the subsequent exams would you have this patient undergo?
A. Bilateral mammography
B. PET scan
C. Biopsy of the breast mass
D. USG guided biopsy of the lymph node
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) A, C & D

The given clinical scenario is s/o breast malignancy with locoregional spread without distant metastasis. 

Therefore for further evaluation, mammography, breast biopsy and biopsy of the lymph node should be performed. 

PET scan is usually performed in advanced cases of breast cancer and not routinely done in assessment of locoregional disease. 



Fig: Triple Assessment in Breast Investigation

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 915.

choices.text: Helps to Diagnose cancer in Genital Tract
Helps to Diagnose other associated Genital infections in the Patient

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman who frequently contracts Trichomonas vaginalis infection visits the gynecology outpatient department.
She was told to get a PAP Smear. She is curious about the purpose of this test and enquires about the same. What will be the appropriate response?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Helps to Screen for Cervical Cancer
 

A Pap smear, or Papanicolaou test, is primarily used to screen for cervical cancer by detecting precancerous or cancerous changes in cervical cells. While it can sometimes incidentally detect infections like Trichomonas vaginalis or other abnormalities, its primary purpose is not to diagnose infections but to catch early signs of cervical cancer.

Other options:

  1. Helps to Diagnose cancer in Genital Tract: While the Pap smear can help in identifying precancerous or cancerous cells in the cervix, it’s not a diagnostic tool for all genital tract cancers.
  2. Helps to demonstrate Trichomonas vaginalis infection: Although Trichomonas may occasionally be seen in a Pap smear, other tests like a wet mount or NAAT are more reliable for diagnosing infections.
  3. Helps to Diagnose other associated Genital infections in the Patient: Pap smears are not specifically designed for diagnosing infections.



Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 364.

choices.text: Continuous Electronic FHR monitoring is required for Breech during labour
Vaginal Breech Delivery is allowed in Hospitals where the facilities for Emergency Caesarian section is available
Breech diagnosed for the First time in Labour is contraindicated for Vaginal delivery
Vaginal breech delivery should be attempted in settings where trained person present

questions.text: All are true about Breech presentation in Labour except:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Breech diagnosed for the First time in Labour is contraindicated for Vaginal delivery

Trial for vaginal delivery can be given to breech in labor provided facilities for emergency cesarean section are present.

Unfavourable for vaginal breech birth :

• other contraindications to vaginal birth (e.g. placenta, previa, compromised fetal condition)
• clinically inadequate pelvis 
• footling or kneeling breech presentation 
• large baby (usually defined as larger than 3800 g)
• growth-restricted baby (usually defined as smaller than 2000 g)
• Hyperextented fetal neck in labour (diagnosed with ultrasound or X-ray where ultrasound is not available )
• lack of presence of a clinician trained in vaginal breech delivery 
• previous caesarean section 



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 519.
DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition, Page no 357.

questions.text:
Which of the following symptoms is present in a child who has hypertrophic pyloric stenosis?
i. Non-bilious vomiting
ii. Visible peristalsis from Left to Right in Abdomen
iii. Palpable mass in abdomen
iv. Hypochlorimia, Hypokalemia,Metabolic acidosis
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1. i, ii, iii

All of the following can be seen in cases of Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis.

Clinical features of pyloric stenosis-
  • Seen during the third and sixth weeks of life.
  • Forceful, projectile, and non-bilious vomiting
  • Presence of visible gastric peristalsis (VGP) from left to right 
  • Palpable lump of hypertrophied pylorus- from the left side, a movable, smooth, firm, olive-like mass with all borders well defined, moves with respiration, and has poor resonance on percussion.
  • Constipation
  • Dehydration and weight loss
  • Hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis and electrolyte imbalance.
 
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 259.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old boy complained of c/o bedwetting nearly twice a week. To rule out any organic cause, a thorough investigation
was conducted. Parents and child are concerned about his condition. What early management is most effective?
questions.solution:
The child is suffering from Nocturnal Enuresis.
  • Bell and pad based classical conditioning is the most effective treatment modality.
Methods of treating Nocturnal Enuresis:
  1. Reassure parents and tell them about the self limiting nature of the disorder.
  2. Motivational therapy can be used.
  3. Conditioning with Bell and pad alarm method can be used.
  4. Pharmacotherapy

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 1216.

questions.text: A 14-month-old infant with hemoglobin levels of 6.2g/dl required frequent blood transfusions. There are multiple target cells on peripheral smear. Nine months have passed since the final transfusion. Which is the definitive diagnosis investigation?
questions.solution:
Decreased haemoglobin levels, multiple target cells on peripheral, smear and history of multiple blood transfusions point towards Thalassaemia.
  • In cases of thalassaemia, definitive diagnosis is done though Globin gene sequencing.
  • Investigations for haemoglobin disorders include:
  1. Screening by haemoglobin electrophoresis.
  2. Investigation of choice is HPLC.
  3. Definitive diagnosis though globin gene sequencing.



Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 339-341
